page.title: 4.11.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will learn to identify the inputs and outputs as the domain and range of a function. You will calculate real-world examples using money, area, and perimeter to understand how the use of the domain and range of a function can be applied in everyday life.

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Describe the “domain” and “range” of a function.
  • Determine a reasonable domain and range for the function when given a description of a function in a situation.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 4.11.1: Determining Reasonable Inputs and Outputs
  • 4.11.2: Domain: The Input of a Function
  • 4.11.2: Self Check
  • 4.11.3: Range: The Output of a Function
  • 4.11.3: Self Check
  • 4.11.4: Using Graphs to Determine the Domain of a Function (Optional)
  • 4.11.5: Using Functions to Answer Real-World Questions

After that, you’ll practice and review.

  • 4.11.6: Practice
  • 4.11.7: Lesson Summary

page.title: 4.11.1: Determining Reasonable Inputs and Outputs
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity

Earlier, you saw a situation where the total number of times a dog has barked was a function of the time, in seconds, after its owner tied its leash to a post and left. Less than 3 minutes after he left, the owner returned, untied the leash, and walked away with the dog.


  1. Could each value be an input of the function? Enter yes or no. Be prepared to explain your reasoning.

    1. 15 seconds

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

Yes


    1. \(84\frac12\) seconds

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

Yes


    1. 300 seconds

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

No. The owner returned in under 180 seconds and then walked away with the dog, so 300 seconds is not a possible input (assuming that the function is limited to the time the dog was tied to the leash and when the owner was away).


  1. Could each value be an output of the function? Be prepared to explain your reasoning.

    1. 15

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

Yes


    1. \(84\frac12\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

No. It is not possible for the dog to bark a fractional number of times.


    1. 300

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

Yes

page.title: 4.11.2: Domain: The Input of a Function
page.contents:
Activity

Your teacher will give you a set of cards that each contain a number. Decide whether each number is a possible input for the functions described here. Sort the cards into two groups: possible inputs and impossible inputs. Record your sorting decisions.


  1. The area of a square, in square centimeters, is a function of its side length, \(s\), in centimeters. The equation \(A(s) =s^2\) defines this function.

    1. Possible inputs:

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

Possible inputs: \(9\), \(\frac35\), \(15\), \(0\), \(0.8\), \(4\), \(\frac{25}4\), \(0.001\), \(6.8\), \(72\)


    1. Impossible inputs:

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

Impossible inputs: –3, –18



  1. A tennis camp charges $40 per student for a full-day camp. The camp only runs if at least 5 students sign up, and it limits the enrollment to 16 campers a day. The amount of revenue, in dollars, that the tennis camp collects is a function of the number of students who enroll.
    The equation \(R(n)=40n\) defines this function.

    1. Possible inputs:

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

Possible inputs: 9, 15



    1. Impossible inputs:

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

Impossible inputs: \(-3\), \(-18\), \(\frac35\), \(0.8\), \(0\), \(\frac{25}4\), \(0.001\), \(4\), \(6.8\), \(72\)



  1. The relationship between temperature in Celsius and the temperature in Kelvin can be represented by a function \(k\). The equation \(k(c)=c+273.15\) defines this function, where \(c\) is the temperature in Celsius and \(k(c)\) is the temperature in Kelvin.

    1. Possible inputs:

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Possible inputs: All values



    1. Impossible inputs:

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Impossible inputs: No values


Write this definition in your math notebook: The domain of a function is the set of all of its possible input values.

page.title: 4.11.2: Self Check
page.contents:
Jose created a function \(W(h)\) for the weight, \(W\), of his family members given their height, \(h\), in inches.

Which of the following provides a group of possible inputs for the function?

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Height cannot be negative. The answer is \(47\), \(50.2\), \(60\frac12\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: A height of 5 inches is not realistic. The answer is \(47\), \(50.2\), \(60\frac12\).
That’s correct! Check yourself: Height can be expressed in fractions and decimals, and these are reasonable values for the input in inches.
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Height cannot be negative. The answer is \(47\), \(50.2\), \(60\frac12\).

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 4.11.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Finding Possible Input Values

Micah mows lawns every week at a function \(M\), number of lawns mowed, as a function of \(d\), days, represented by the equation \(M(d)=4d\). He always finishes a lawn that he starts to mow.


Which of the following are possible inputs?

  1. –2

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

No. It is not possible for him to work a negative number of days.



Which of the following are possible inputs?

  1. 0

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Yes



Which of the following are possible inputs?

  1. 2.5

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Yes



Which of the following are possible inputs?

  1. 4

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Yes


Note: Fractions, decimals, and negative numbers are all allowed as input values but may be eliminated depending on the context of the problem that the function represents.

Try It: Finding Possible Input Values

Elena runs at a constant speed. Her distance, \(D\), in miles is a function of the time, \(t\), in minutes. Her running distance is represented by the function \(D(t)=9t\).


Which of the following are possible input values?

\(-7\), \(\frac23\), \(45\), \(60.5\)

In your notebook, write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Here is how to find the possible input values:

–7 is not possible because she cannot run for a negative amount of time

\(\frac23\) is possible. However, it is not always reasonable because it stands for \(\frac23\) of one minute. It is important to always look at the entire problem to see if there are any other restrictions, like a minimum amount of time running.

45 and 60.5 are both possible input values because she could run for 45 minutes or 60.5 minutes.

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 4.11.3: Range: The Output of a Function
page.contents:
Activity

In an earlier activity, you saw a function representing the area of a square (function \(A\)) and another representing the revenue of a tennis camp (function \(R\)). Refer to the descriptions of those functions to answer these questions.

  1. Here is a graph that represents function \(A\), defined by \(A(s)=s^2\), where \(s\) is the side length of the square in centimeters.



  1. Name three possible input-output pairs of this function.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

\(A(2)=4\), \(A(3)=9\), and \(A(7)=49\), or \((2,4)\), \((3,9)\), \((7,49)\)



  1. Earlier, we described the set of all possible input values of \(A\) as “any number greater than or equal to 0.” How would you describe the set of all possible output values of \(A\)?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

The outputs of \(A\) are also all numbers greater than or equal to 0.



  1. Function \(R\) is defined by \(R(n)=40n\), where \(n\) is the number of campers.
  1. Is 20 a possible output value in this situation? What about 100? Explain your reasoning.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

No, both 20 and 100 cannot be outputs because the input (the number of campers) cannot be fractions.



  1. Here are two graphs that relate number of students and camp revenue in dollars. Which graph could represent function \(R\)? Explain why the other one could not represent the function.


Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

The second graph could represent function \(R\). The first graph could not represent function \(R\) because it includes all points for \(n\)-values between 0 and 5, \(n\)-values greater than 16, and fractional \(n\)-values. All of these \(n\)-values don’t apply in this situation.



  1. Describe the set of all possible output values of \(R\).

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

The outputs of \(R\) are all multiples of 40 between 200 and 640 (200, 240, 280, and so on).


Write the following definition in your math notebook: The set of output values form the range of the function.

Video: Identifying Outputs of a Function

Watch the following video to learn more about identifying outputs of a function.



Making a Real-World Connection

If the camp wishes to collect at least $500 from the participants, how many students can they have? Explain how this information is shown on the graph.

Write your answer here:

Compare your answers:

They will need at least 13 students to collect $500 or more, so the possibilities are 13, 14, 15, and 16. On the graph, there are only 4 dots that lie on or above the horizontal line representing $500.

page.title: 4.11.3: Self Check
page.contents: Looking at the graph below, which statement about the values graphed is true?

answer.answer_text: The largest output value is 8.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: When graphed, the largest input value is 8 since it is an \(x\)-value in the point \((8,19)\). The  answer is the largest output value is 19.

answer.answer_text: The largest output value is 19.
answer.response: That’s correct! Check yourself: The largest \(y\)-value graphed is 19, so that is the largest output.

answer.answer_text: The largest input value is 19.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Since 19 in the point \((8,19)\) is a \(y\)-coordinate, it is an output value. The answer is the largest output value is 19.

answer.answer_text: All odd numbers are outputs.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: While the output values are odd numbers, the numbers in the outputs do not begin until 7. The answer is the largest output value is 19.

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 4.11.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Naming Input-Output Pairs

A graph is yet another way that a relation can be represented. The set of ordered pairs of all the points plotted is the relation. The set of all \(x\)-coordinates, or the input values, is the domain of the relation, and the set of all \(y\)-coordinates, or outputs, is the range.

Recall a coordinate is written \((x, y)\).

Name the input-output pairs for the graph below:

The input values are the \(x\)-values, and the output values are the \(y\)-values.

\((1, 3)\) \((2, 6)\) \((3, 12)\) \((4, 24)\)

Try It: Naming Input-Output Pairs

Name the input-output pairs of the graph below:

In your notebook, write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Here is how to write the input-output pairs:

\((1, 4.5)\) \((2, 9)\) \((3, 18)\) \((4,36)\)

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 4.11.4: Using Graphs to Determine the Domain of a Function (Optional)
page.contents:
Activity

Consider the function \(f(x) = \frac{6}{x-2}\).

To find out the sets of possible input and output values of the function, Clare created a table and evaluated \(f\) at some values of \(x\). Along the way, she ran into some trouble.

  1. Find \(f(x)\) for each \(x\)-value Clare listed. Describe what Clare’s trouble might be.

\(x\)

–10

0

\(\frac12\)

2

8

\(f(x)\)





Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

When \(x\) is \(2\), \(f(x)\) is \(\frac60\), which is undefined.

\(x\)

–10

0

12

2

8

\(f(x)\)

–12

–3

–4

\(\frac60\)

1



  1. Use graphing technology to graph function \(f\). What do you notice about the graph?


Use the graphing tool here or technology outside the course. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:

The graph splits where the \(x\)-value is around 2. See graph. Rational function origin 



  1. Use a calculator to compute the value you and Clare had trouble computing. What do you notice about the computation?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

When I tried to find \(f(2)\) with a calculator, it gave an error message.



  1. How would you describe the domain of function \(f\)?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The domain includes all numbers except 2.


Extending Your Thinking

Why do you think the graph of function f looks the way it does? Why are there two parts that split at \(x=2\), with one curving down as it approaches \(x=2\) from the left and the other curving up as it approaches \(x=2\) from the right?

Evaluate function f at different x-values that approach 2 but are not exactly 2, such as 1.8, 1.9, 1.95, 1.999, 2.2, 2.1, 2.05, 2.001, and so on. What do you notice about the values of \(f(x)\) as the x-values get closer and closer to 2?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

  • When x is less than 2, as it gets closer to 2 (from the left side), the denominator in 6x-2becomes a smaller and smaller negative value, so the quotient, \(f(x)\), gets larger and larger in the negative direction. It does so very quickly, which explains why the curve bends down rather dramatically.
  • When x is greater than 2, as it approaches 2 (from the right side), the denominator in \(6x-2\) becomes a smaller and smaller positive value, so \(f(x)\) gets larger and larger in the positive direction. It does so very quickly as well, which explains the graph shooting up if we trace it from right to left.
  • The expression \(6x-2\) undefined at \(x=2\) and we can see that the two pieces of the graph shoot off in opposite directions as x approaches 2 from the left and from the right, which explains the gap at \(x=2\).

page.title: 4.11.5: Using Functions to Answer Real-World Questions
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity

Diego’s club earns money for charity when members of the club perform community service after school. For each student who does community service, the club earns $5. There are 12 students in the club.

The total dollar amount earned, \(E\), is a function of the number of members who perform community service, \(n\).



  1. Is 5 a possible input value? Why or why not?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(n=5\) is possible. It means that 5 students perform community service.



  1. Is 24 a possible output value? Why or why not?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

No, 24 is not possible as an output value. An output value has to be a multiple of 5.



  1. Describe the domain of this function.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

All integers from 0 to 12



  1. Describe the range of this function.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Multiples of 5 from 0 to 60

page.title: 4.11.6: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

  1. The cost for an upcoming field trip is $15 per student. The cost of the field trip C, in dollars, is a function of the number of students x.

    Select all the possible outputs for the function defined by \(C(x)=15x\).

Correct! 30, 90

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 4.11.1-4.11.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answers are 30, 90. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. A rectangle has an area of  \(24cm^2\). Function f gives the length of the rectangle, in centimeters when the width is \(w cm\). 

    Determine which values, in centimeters, are possible inputs of the function. 

    Select all that apply.

Correct!  Possible: 3, 0.5, 48. Not possible: -6, 0.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 4.11.1-4.11.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answers are: Possible: 3, 0.5, 48. Not possible: -6, 0. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Select all the possible input-output pairs for the function \(\left(\frac{1}{2}, \frac{1}{8}\right)\).

Correct!  \((-1,-1)\), \(\left(\frac12,\frac18\right)\), \((4,64)\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 4.11.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answers are: \((1,-1)\), \(\left(\frac12,\frac18\right)\), \((4,64)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Two functions are defined by the equations \(f(x)=5−0.2x\) and \(g(x)=0.2(x+5)\).
     
    Select all statements that are true about the functions.

Correct! 

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 4.11.3? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answers are \(f(3)>0\), \(g(-1)=0.8\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Is the relation graphed below a function?

Correct! No, this is not a function because 4 maps to both -1 and −3.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 4.11.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is; No, this is not a function because 4 maps to both -1 and −3. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Is the relation graphed below a function?

Correct! no; This is not a function because −3 maps to both 4 and −4.

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 4.11.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is no; This is not a function because −3 maps to both 4 and −4. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. For a fundraiser, \(Chi\) and her class are having a talent show and charging $7 a ticket. There are 100 seats in the theater. The function \(T\), gives the total for selling n tickets and is represented by \(T(n)=7n\). Describe the domain of the function.
    1. Enter the minimum domain value.

      Enter Answer Here: Enter Only Integers

Correct! The minimum domain value is 0

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 4.11.5. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is that the minimum domain value is 0. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. Enter the maximum domain value.

      Enter Answer Here: Enter Only Integers

Correct! The maximum domain value is 100.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 4.11.5. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is that the maximum domain value is 100. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. For a fundraiser, Chi and her class are having a talent show and charging $7 a ticket. There are 100 seats in the theater. The function \(T\), gives the total for selling \(n\) tickets and is represented by \(T(n)=7n\). Is 30 a possible output in the range?

Correct! No; 30 is not a possible value in the range because all values of the range must be multiples of 7.

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 4.11.5 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is 30 is not a possible value in the range because all values of the range must be multiples of 7. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

page.title: 4.11.7: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Describe the “domain” and “range” of a function.
  • Determine a reasonable domain and range for the function when given a description of a function in a situation.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 4.11.1: Determining Reasonable Inputs and Outputs
    • In this activity, you worked to decide if inputs and outputs were reasonable in functions given the context of a situation.
  • 4.11.2: Domain: The Input of a Function
    • In this activity, you determined which inputs are possible and which are impossible through a card sort activity. You noticed the reasonableness of an input depends on the situation’s context.
  • 4.11.2: Self Check 
  • 4.11.3: Range: The Output of a Function
    • In this activity, you identified possible outputs of a function to make the range. You also identified input-output pairs from graphs.
  • 4.11.3: Self Check 
  • 4.11.4: Using Graphs to Determine the Domain of a Function (Optional)
    • In this optional activity, you explored what happens when an input gives an undefined output.
  • 4.11.5: Using Functions to Answer-Real World Questions
    • In this activity, you answered real-world questions by describing the elements of the domain and range of a given situation.

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 4.11.6: Practice

Checking In

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If you’ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.
